unit_title: Magnetic Force on a Current-Carrying Wire
subject: AP Physics 2
expanded_description: Comprehensive study of magnetic forces on current-carrying conductors, including force calculations for straight wires, force on arbitrary current paths, and applications to electric motors and other electromagnetic devices.
learning_objectives: Calculate magnetic force on straight current-carrying wires
Apply the right-hand rule for force direction on current elements
Determine net force on complex current paths in magnetic fields
Analyze torque on current loops in magnetic fields
Apply magnetic force principles to electric motor operation
Solve problems involving forces between current-carrying wires
Calculate work and energy in magnetic force systems
Design simple electromagnetic devices using force principles

classifications.note: Force on straight wire: $\vec{F} = I\vec{L} \times \vec{B}$; Magnitude: $F = ILB\sin\theta$; Maximum when $\theta = 90^\circ$ ($\sin\theta = 1$); Zero when $\theta = 0^\circ$ ($\sin\theta = 0$); Direction: right-hand rule

principles.statement: Magnetic forces on current-carrying wires follow fundamental principles: Force Equation: $\vec{F} = I\vec{L} \times \vec{B}$ for straight wire in uniform field; $\vec{L}$ points in current direction with magnitude = wire length. Magnitude Calculation: $F = ILB\sin\theta$; $\theta$ = angle between current direction and magnetic field; Maximum: $F_{max} = ILB$ when $\theta = 90^\circ$; Zero when $\theta = 0^\circ$ or $180^\circ$. Direction Determination: Right-hand rule: point fingers in current direction, curl toward magnetic field, thumb gives force direction; Alternative: $\vec{L} \times \vec{B}$ gives direction. Derivation from Lorentz Force: Force on single charge: $\vec{F} = q\vec{v}_d \times \vec{B}$; Current: $I = nqAv_d$; Total force: $\vec{F} = (nAL)(q\vec{v}_d \times \vec{B}) = I\vec{L} \times \vec{B}$. Work and Energy: Magnetic force does no work on current elements; Force perpendicular to current direction; Energy comes from electrical source maintaining current. Special Cases: Wire parallel to B: $F = 0$; Wire perpendicular to B: $F = ILB$; Arbitrary angle: $F = ILB\sin\theta$. Unit Analysis: 1 N = 1 A·m·T; 1 T = 1 N/(A·m).
principles.application: Calculate magnetic force magnitude on straight wires. Determine force direction using right-hand rules. Analyze force for different current-field orientations. Solve for unknown variables in force equation. Apply force principles to simple electromagnetic systems. Verify force perpendicularity to current and field.
principles.example: Calculate force on wire in given magnetic field. Determine force direction for specific configuration. Analyze force variation with orientation angle. Solve for required current to produce specific force.
principles.analogy: Like wind pushing on a sail - the force depends on both the wind direction (magnetic field) and how the sail is oriented (current direction), with maximum push when the sail is perpendicular to the wind and no push when parallel to it

sections.section_title: 2. Forces on Complex Current Paths and Loops
sections.introduction: Analyzing magnetic forces on arbitrary current paths, calculating net forces on closed loops, and understanding torque development on current-carrying loops.

key_concept.definition: Force on current element $d\vec{F} = I d\vec{l} \times \vec{B}$, Net force on closed loop, Torque on current loop, Magnetic moment, Motor principle
key_concept.context: For arbitrary current paths, the magnetic force is calculated by integrating the force on infinitesimal current elements, with closed loops in uniform magnetic fields experiencing zero net force but potentially developing torque.

classifications.value: Classification based on current path geometry and field uniformity
characteristics: Closed loops in uniform field: zero net force
Closed loops in uniform field: possible torque

classifications.note: Force on element: $d\vec{F} = I d\vec{l} \times \vec{B}$; Net force: $\vec{F} = I \oint d\vec{l} \times \vec{B}$; For uniform B: $\vec{F} = I (\oint d\vec{l}) \times \vec{B} = 0$ for closed loop; Torque: $\vec{\tau} = \vec{\mu} \times \vec{B}$ where $\vec{\mu} = NI\vec{A}$

principles.principle: Forces on Complex Current Paths and Loops
principles.statement: Magnetic forces on complex paths follow specific principles: General Force Equation: $d\vec{F} = I d\vec{l} \times \vec{B}$ for infinitesimal current element; Total force: $\vec{F} = I \int d\vec{l} \times \vec{B}$. Closed Loops in Uniform B: Net force is zero: $\vec{F} = I (\oint d\vec{l}) \times \vec{B} = 0$ since $\oint d\vec{l} = 0$; But torque may exist. Torque on Current Loop: Magnetic moment: $\vec{\mu} = NI\vec{A}$; N = number of turns, I = current, $\vec{A}$ = area vector (normal to loop); Torque: $\vec{\tau} = \vec{\mu} \times \vec{B}$; Magnitude: $\tau = \mu B\sin\theta$. Rectangular Loop Example: Forces on opposite sides are equal and opposite; Creates torque but no net force; Maximum torque when plane parallel to B; Zero torque when plane perpendicular to B. Magnetic Moment: $\vec{\mu} = NI\vec{A}$; Direction: right-hand rule along normal; Units: A·m²; Analogous to electric dipole moment. Energy of Magnetic Dipole: Potential energy: $U = -\vec{\mu} \cdot \vec{B} = -\mu B\cos\theta$; Minimum energy when $\vec{\mu} \parallel \vec{B}$; Maximum when $\vec{\mu} \parallel -\vec{B}$. Non-uniform Fields: Net force exists on loops in non-uniform B; Force direction: toward stronger field for aligned dipoles.
principles.application: Calculate net force on arbitrary current paths. Determine torque on current loops in magnetic fields. Analyze magnetic moment and its orientation. Solve for equilibrium positions of current loops. Calculate work done in rotating current loops. Apply loop principles to motor design.
principles.example: Calculate net force on semicircular wire. Determine torque on rectangular loop. Find equilibrium orientation of current loop. Analyze energy changes during loop rotation.
principles.analogy: Like a paddle wheel in a river - the water pushes on all paddles, but if the wheel is symmetric, there's no net forward force (like net force on closed loop), but there can be a turning effect (torque) that makes the wheel rotate

worked_examples.title: Net Force on Semicircular Wire
worked_examples.problem: A semicircular wire of radius R carries current I in a uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to the plane of the semicircle. Calculate the net magnetic force on the wire.

step_by_step.explanation: The semicircle has symmetry about the diameter
The diameter segment: current elements parallel to each other but not necessarily to B
Each current element on curve has different orientation to B
For uniform B, net force depends only on straight-line distance between endpoints
Straight-line distance between ends of semicircle = 2R

worked_examples.final_answer: Net force = $2IRB$ directed perpendicular to both the diameter and magnetic field; Equivalent to force on straight wire of length 2R

classifications.note: Force between parallel wires: $F/L = \frac{\mu_0 I_1 I_2}{2\pi d}$; Ampere definition: force between infinite parallel wires 1 m apart with 1 A current = 2 × 10⁻⁷ N/m; Applications: motors, speakers, relays, MRI, particle accelerators

principles.statement: Magnetic force applications employ specific principles: Electric Motors: DC motor: commutator reverses current to maintain rotation; Torque: $\tau = NIAB\sin\theta$; Back EMF develops during operation. Loudspeakers: Voice coil in permanent magnet field; Current proportional to sound signal; Force: $F = BIL$ causes cone motion. Galvanometers: Current measurement devices; Torque proportional to current: $\tau = NIAB$; Spring provides restoring torque. Force Between Parallel Wires: Each wire in the other's magnetic field; Field from wire: $B = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi r}$; Force per unit length: $\frac{F}{L} = \frac{\mu_0 I_1 I_2}{2\pi d}$; Like currents attract, unlike currents repel. Ampere Definition: 1 ampere = current that produces $2 \times 10^{-7}$ N/m force between parallel wires 1 m apart. Magnetic Levitation: Repulsive forces between currents and magnets; Used in maglev trains; Requires superconducting currents for large forces. Circuit Protection: Magnetic circuit breakers; High current produces large magnetic force; Trips mechanism to break circuit. Energy Conversion: Motors: electrical → mechanical energy; Generators: mechanical → electrical energy; Efficiency considerations.
principles.application: Analyze electric motor operation and design. Calculate forces in loudspeaker systems. Design galvanometers for current measurement. Solve problems involving forces between currents. Apply ampere definition in calculations. Design simple electromagnetic devices.
principles.example: Calculate torque in DC motor. Design loudspeaker voice coil. Determine force between parallel wires. Analyze magnetic circuit breaker operation.
principles.analogy: Like teams in a tug-of-war - parallel wires with currents in the same direction pull together (attract), while wires with opposite currents push apart (repel), with the rope tension representing the magnetic force between them

common_misconceptions: Thinking magnetic force can do work on current-carrying wires
Believing net force on closed loop is always zero
Assuming force direction doesn't depend on current direction
Thinking torque depends on loop shape beyond area
Assuming magnetic forces can create energy
Thinking the right-hand rule is arbitrary convention
real_world_applications: Electric motors in appliances and vehicles
summary: Current-carrying wires experience magnetic forces given by $\vec{F} = I\vec{L} \times \vec{B}$ for straight segments, with magnitude $F = ILB\sin\theta$ and direction determined by the right-hand rule. For arbitrary paths, the force is calculated using $d\vec{F} = I d\vec{l} \times \vec{B}$ and integration. Closed current loops in uniform magnetic fields experience zero net force but develop torque $\vec{\tau} = \vec{\mu} \times \vec{B}$, where the magnetic moment is $\vec{\mu} = NI\vec{A}$. Parallel current-carrying wires exert forces on each other given by $F/L = \frac{\mu_0 I_1 I_2}{2\pi d}$, with like currents attracting and unlike currents repelling. These principles enable numerous applications including electric motors (using torque on current loops), loudspeakers (using force on voice coils), galvanometers (using torque for measurement), and the definition of the ampere based on forces between parallel currents. Magnetic forces do no work, serving only to transfer energy between different forms or redirect motion.
